A set is a collection of distinct objects considered as an entity.
Prime Subfield of a Finite Field
The prime subfield of a finite field $\\[\mathbb{F}\]$ is the smallest subfield contained within $\\[\mathbb{F}\]$, denoted as $\\[\mathbb{F}_p\]$, where $p=\operatorname{char} \\[\mathbb{F}\]>0$.
Does the concept of a/an Set need to be defined for a definition of a/an Prime Subfield of a Finite Field to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: To determine if the concept of a Set is necessary for the definition of a Prime Subfield of a Finite Field, we need to analyze the components of the latter definition. A finite field $\mathbb{F}$ is a set with additional algebraic structure (it is equipped with two operations: addition and multiplication). The definition of a prime subfield $\mathbb{F}_p$ refers to it being the smallest subfield contained within $\mathbb{F}$. A subfield, by definition, is itself a set that satisfies the field properties under the same operations defined on $\mathbb{F}$. Therefore, the concept of a set is fundamental because both a field and a subfield are special kinds of sets. Without the concept of a set, the notion of a subfield, and hence the prime subfield, would not make sense as there would be no way to define the collection of elements that constitute these algebraic structures.
